citation.article-title: Atopobacter phocae gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel bacterium isolated from common seals.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Atopobacter (A.to.po.bac'ter. Gr. adj. atopos having no place, strange; M.L. masc. n. bacter rod; M.L. masc. n. Atopobacter, strange rod)
Cells consist of Gram-positive, short, non-sporeforming, irregular rods.
Non-haemolytic, small pinsized, grey-coloured, smooth colonies are formed on horse blood agar after incubation at 37 °C for 24 h.
Growth is observed without the addition of blood or serum to the basal medium.
Growth is observed at 25 but not at 42 °C.
Acid but no gas is produced from D-glucose.
Acid phosphatase, arginine dihydrolase, alkaline phosphatase and pyrrolidonyl arylamidase are produced.
Aesculin, gelatin, hippurate and urea are not hydrolysed.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
The cell wall contains an L-Orn-D-Asp-type murein (A4β).
The type species of the genus is Atopobacter phocae.

As determined by 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis, the genus Atopobacter belongs to the lactic acid group of bacteria and is phylogenetically most closely related to G. adiacens, G. balaenopterae and G. elegans.
